protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
description:
Protocol for collecting gas for measurement of carbon isotope descrimination during photosynthesis.

 

See the following references for more background:

H. Griffiths (1993) Photosynthesis and Production in a Changing Environment pp 181-1927

Farquhar et al.  (1989) Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. Plant Mol. Bioi. 1989. 40:503-37
keywords: Photosynthesis, Plant physiology, carbon isotope descrimination
status_info: We are still developing and optimizing this protocol

components.data: Preparing plant for measurement
components.name: Section

components.data:
• Clamp leaf in cuvette, under a bright ambient light. 
  • Adjust H2OR so that Tleaf is around 25 oC. This will need adjusting when leaf is reaching stability in the cuvette.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
• Clamp leaf in cuvette, under a bright ambient light. 
  • Adjust H2OR so that Tleaf is around 25 oC. This will need adjusting when leaf is reaching stability in the cuvette.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 1 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas
source_data.protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.annotation:
For tobacco a 4 week old plant prior to flowering is in the ideal state (health example below).

Make sure not to stress the plant by introducing tension when clamping.

 

Illuminate from above (at least 200µE), this makes sure the surrounding leaf tissue is photosynthesising to reduce chance of diffusion of metabolites influencing measurements, this is more important for homobaric leaves such as tobacco.

 

It helps to let the plant acclimate in the lab for ~24h prior to measurement.

 

 

 

Wait with measurements and CO2 trapping until complete steady state has been reached. 

  •         Assimilation rate (A) and steady state fluorescence do not change over time (10 min window)
  •         Stomatal conductance (gs) does not change over time (10 min window)

This can take ~2h depending on the plant. Check regularly (~every 15 mins after the first half hour)

 

Note that mesophyll conductance can be altered by a whole range of factors (cell size, leaf expansion, age of leaf etc etc) so care should be taken in performing comparisons and should try to keep to plants at a consistent developmental stage and growth conditions.

  •         Assimilation rate (A) and steady state fluorescence do not change over time (10 min window)
  •         Stomatal conductance (gs) does not change over time (10 min window)

This can take ~2h depending on the plant. Check regularly (~every 15 mins after the first half hour)

 

Note that mesophyll conductance can be altered by a whole range of factors (cell size, leaf expansion, age of leaf etc etc) so care should be taken in performing comparisons and should try to keep to plants at a consistent developmental stage and growth conditions.

It helps to let the plant acclimate in the lab for ~24h prior to measurement.

  •         Assimilation rate (A) and steady state fluorescence do not change over time (10 min window)

This can take ~2h depending on the plant. Check regularly (~every 15 mins after the first half hour)

source_data.annotation:
This will be used to cool down acetone to below -70oC as required for sublimination of frozen CO2

There is only an ON/OFF setting.
source_data.thread_text:
This will be used to cool down acetone to below -70oC as required for sublimination of frozen CO2

There is only an ON/OFF setting.
source_data.body:

components.data: Place cold finger in dewar of acetone and wait to cool down (>-70oC), it should turn milky white
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place cold finger in dewar of acetone and wait to cool down (>-70oC), it should turn milky white

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 3 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas
source_data.protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.annotation: Cover the top of the dewar with foli to prevent ice forming and falling into the acetone. Do not rest the finger on the bottom of the dewar otherwise an ice lump forms and it will stick

source_data.annotation: These will be used to condense gases for sample collection. This can be done whilst waiting for the acetone to cool down

components.data: Open glass valves and wait until vacuum gauge reads around 5.5 mbar on each prep line. Adjust by opening/closing pump valves if required.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Open glass valves and wait until vacuum gauge reads around 5.5 mbar on each prep line. Adjust by opening/closing pump valves if required.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 8 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas
source_data.protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.annotation:
Provide support from below when opening/closing valve. Apply downward pressure while twisting to minimize the chance of introducing leaks (this is the most common source in the system).

 

Adjust the vacuum pressure by opening the valve to the pump (red arrow). This ensures that approximately the same amount of gas is collected for reference and sample and ensures consistency between measurements
source_data.thread_text:

Check settings

  • automatch OFF
  • Fluorescence OFF

components.data: Start Measurement
components.name: Section

components.data:
Set the following environmental variables in the LICOR LI-6800

 

CO2S

400 ppm

Txchg

25 oC

H2OR

10-14 mbar (aim for Tleaf 25 oC)

PAR

2000 (100% Red)

Flow

250 ml min-1

Fan speed

14500 rpm

deltaP

0.1 kPa
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Set the following environmental variables in the LICOR LI-6800

 

CO2S

400 ppm

Txchg

25 oC

H2OR

10-14 mbar (aim for Tleaf 25 oC)

PAR

2000 (100% Red)

Flow

250 ml min-1

Fan speed

14500 rpm

deltaP

0.1 kPa

components.data: Setting up IRGA
components.name: Section

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 1 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas
source_data.protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.annotation:
Control temperature on block (Txchg), not leaf otherwise photosynthetic rate will start to oscillate due to constant adjustment of stomata.

 

TLeaf should ideally be within +/- 0.03oC of 25oC as measurement is temperature sensitive. 25oC is the value that C3 photosynthetic calculations are parematerized for. You can manipulate with humidity or Txchg on reference
source_data.thread_text:
Control temperature on block (Txchg), not leaf otherwise photosynthetic rate will start to oscillate due to constant adjustment of stomata.

 

TLeaf should ideally be within +/- 0.03oC of 25oC as measurement is temperature sensitive. 25oC is the value that C3 photosynthetic calculations are parematerized for. You can manipulate with humidity or Txchg on reference

components.data:
When plant has reached a steady state switch inlet gas to 2% oxygen. Use a flow controller to moderate gas use, setting flow to ~6.

Change the constant value in LICOR
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
When plant has reached a steady state switch inlet gas to 2% oxygen. Use a flow controller to moderate gas use, setting flow to ~6.

Change the constant value in LICOR

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 7 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas
source_data.protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.annotation:
2% O2 is used to suppress photorespiration simplifying downstream calculations of carbon flux. Note this will change assimilation and photosynthesis values which will take time to stabilize again, you may witness oscillations in A and F which will dampen down over time.

 

When there is no flow the value should be ~0.5 or less

If the cylinder is running low order a replacement, always keep a backup cylinder to avoid running out of gas
source_data.thread_text:

When there is no flow the value should be ~0.5 or less

If the cylinder is running low order a replacement, always keep a backup cylinder to avoid running out of gas

components.data: Close the glass valves, watch the vacuum drop to low 10-2 or high 10-3E.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 15 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas

source_data.annotation: Twist perpendicular to the flow direction otherwise there can be leaks, check the pressure gauge

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 21 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas
source_data.protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.annotation:
When the vacuum stabilizes all gas has been condensed again, this is the point when you can close tube and remove from LN2

Collect drips of acetone from distillation tube in beaker
source_data.thread_text:
When the vacuum stabilizes all gas has been condensed again, this is the point when you can close tube and remove from LN2

components.data:
Remove collection tube from prep line and leave to thaw in rack

Put new (empty and open) collection tube in place and open pump valve
components.name: Description

Put new (empty and open) collection tube in place and open pump valve

components.data: Quickly submerge the collection tube in LN2 to condense the released gas
components.name: Description

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 19 of Carbon isotope analysis: Trapping gas
source_data.protocol_name: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.protocol_name_html: Carbon isotope descrimination - part I - trapline - v0.1
source_data.annotation:
The pressure should fall again as gas is drawn down into the collection tube. By following this procedure it is possible to collect gases and remove the water vapour from samples which would interfere with measurements

 

Collection tube should be dipped in LN2, covering at least the bottom 2cm
source_data.thread_text:
The pressure should fall again as gas is drawn down into the collection tube. By following this procedure it is possible to collect gases and remove the water vapour from samples which would interfere with measurements

 

Collection tube should be dipped in LN2, covering at least the bottom 2cm
